t: Ecclesiastes 1
The Vanity of Life
The*p words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
“Vanity*pn of vanities,” says the Preacher; “Vanity*ld of vanities, all is*i vanity.”
What*ln profit has a man from all his labor In*ld which he toils under the sun?
One*ild generation passes away, and another*i generation comes; But*ld the earth abides forever.
The*ld sun also rises, and the sun goes down, And*ld hastens to the place where it arose.
The*ld wind goes toward the south, And*ld turns around to the north; The*ld wind whirls about continually, And*ld comes again on its circuit.
All*ld the rivers run into the sea, Yet*ld the sea is*i not full; To*ld the place from which the rivers come, There*ld they return again.
All*ld things are*i full of labor; Man*ld cannot express it.*i The*ld eye is not satisfied with seeing, Nor*ld the ear filled with hearing.
That*ln which has been is*i what will be, That*ld which is*i done is what will be done, And*ld there*i is*i nothing new under the sun.
Is*ld there anything of which it may be said, “See,*ld this is*i new”? It*ld has already been in ancient times before us.
There*ild is*i no remembrance of former things,*i Nor*ld will there be any remembrance of things*i that are to come By*ld those*i who will come after.
The Grief of Wisdom
I,*p the Preacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
And I set my heart to seek and search out by wisdom concerning all that is done under heaven; this burdensome task God has given to the sons of man, by which they may be exercised.
I have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and indeed, all is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
What*ipn is*i crooked cannot be made straight, And*ld what is lacking cannot be numbered.
I*p communed with my heart, saying, “Look, I have attained greatness, and have gained more wisdom than all who were before me in Jerusalem. My heart has understood great wisdom and knowledge.”
And I set my heart to know wisdom and to know madness and folly. I perceived that this also is grasping for the wind.
For*pn in much wisdom is*i much grief, And*ld he who increases knowledge increases sorrow.
Ecclesiastes 2
The Vanity of Pleasure
I*p said in my heart, “Come now, I will test you with mirth; therefore enjoy pleasure”; but surely, this also was*i vanity.
I said of laughter—“Madness!”; and of mirth, “What does it accomplish?”

I searched in my heart how*i to gratify my flesh with wine, while guiding my heart with wisdom, and how to lay hold on folly, till I might see what was*i good for the sons of men to do under heaven all the days of their lives.
I*p made my works great, I built myself houses, and planted myself vineyards.
I made myself gardens and orchards, and I planted all kinds*i of fruit trees in them.
I made myself water pools from which to water the growing trees of the grove.
I acquired male and female servants, and had servants born in my house. Yes, I had greater possessions of herds and flocks than all who were in Jerusalem before me.

I also gathered for myself silver and gold and the special treasures of kings and of the provinces. I acquired male and female singers, the delights of the sons of men, and*i musical instruments of all kinds.
So*p I became great and excelled more than all who were before me in Jerusalem. Also my wisdom remained with me.
Whatever*pn my eyes desired I did not keep from them. I*ld did not withhold my heart from any pleasure, For*ld my heart rejoiced in all my labor; And*ld this was my reward from all my labor.
Then*ld I looked on all the works that my hands had done And*ld on the labor in which I had toiled; And*ld indeed all was*i vanity and grasping for the wind. There*ild was*i no profit under the sun.
The End of the Wise and the Fool
Then*pn I turned myself to consider wisdom and madness and folly; For*ld what can*i the man do*i who succeeds the king?— Only*ild what he has already done.
Then*ld I saw that wisdom excels folly As*ld light excels darkness.
The*ld wise man’s eyes are*i in his head, But*ld the fool walks in darkness. Yet*ld I myself perceived That*ld the same event happens to them all.
So*ln I said in my heart, “As*ld it happens to the fool, It*ld also happens to me, And*ld why was I then more wise?” Then*ld I said in my heart, “This*ld also is*i vanity.”
For*ld there*i is*i no more remembrance of the wise than of the fool forever, Since*ld all that now is*i will be forgotten in the days to come. And*ld how does a wise man*i die? As*ld the fool!
Therefore*p I hated life because the work that was done under the sun was*i distressing to me, for all is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
Then*p I hated all my labor in which I had toiled under the sun, because I must leave it to the man who will come after me.
And who knows whether he will be wise or a fool? Yet he will rule over all my labor in which I toiled and in which I have shown myself wise under the sun. This also is*i vanity.
Therefore I turned my heart and despaired of all the labor in which I had toiled under the sun.
For there is a man whose labor is*i with wisdom, knowledge, and skill; yet he must leave his heritage to a man who has not labored for it. This also is*i vanity and a great evil.
For what has man for all his labor, and for the striving of his heart with which he has toiled under the sun?
For all his days are*i sorrowful, and his work burdensome; even in the night his heart takes no rest. This also is vanity.
Nothing*p is*i better for a man than*i that he should eat and drink, and that*i his soul should enjoy good in his labor. This also, I saw, was from the hand of God.
For who can eat, or who can have enjoyment, more than I?

For God*i gives wisdom and knowledge and joy to a man who is*i good in His sight; but to the sinner He gives the work of gathering and collecting, that he may give to him*i who*i is*i good before God. This also is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
Ecclesiastes 3
Everything Has Its Time
To*pn everything there*i is*i a season, A*ld time for every purpose under heaven:
A*ln time to be born, And*ld a time to die; A*ld time to plant, And*ld a time to pluck what*i is*i planted;
A*ld time to kill, And*ld a time to heal; A*ld time to break down, And*ld a time to build up;
A*ld time to weep, And*ld a time to laugh; A*ld time to mourn, And*ld a time to dance;
A*ld time to cast away stones, And*ld a time to gather stones; A*ld time to embrace, And*ld a time to refrain from embracing;
A*ld time to gain, And*ld a time to lose; A*ld time to keep, And*ld a time to throw away;
A*ld time to tear, And*ld a time to sew; A*ld time to keep silence, And*ld a time to speak;
A*ld time to love, And*ld a time to hate; A*ld time of war, And*ld a time of peace.
The God-Given Task
What*p profit has the worker from that in which he labors?
I have seen the God-given task with which the sons of men are to be occupied.
He has made everything beautiful in its time. Also He has put eternity in their hearts, except that no one can find out the work that God does from beginning to end.
I*p know that nothing is*i better for them than to rejoice, and to do good in their lives,
and also that every man should eat and drink and enjoy the good of all his labor—it is*i the gift of God.
I*pn know that whatever God does, It*ld shall be forever. Nothing*ld can be added to it, And*ld nothing taken from it. God*ld does it,*i that men should fear before Him.
That*ld which is has already been, And*ld what is to be has already been; And*ld God requires an account of what is past.
Injustice Seems to Prevail
Moreover*p I saw under the sun: In*ipn the place of judgment, Wickedness*ld was*i there; And*ld in*i the place of righteousness, Iniquity*ld was*i there.
I*p said in my heart, “God*pn shall judge the righteous and the wicked, For*ld there*i is*i a time there for every purpose and for every work.”
I*p said in my heart, “Concerning the condition of the sons of men, God tests them, that they may see that they themselves are like*i animals.”

For what happens to the sons of men also happens to animals; one thing befalls them: as one dies, so dies the other. Surely, they all have one breath; man has no advantage over animals, for all is*i vanity.
All go to one place: all are from the dust, and all return to dust.
Who knows the spirit of the sons of men, which goes upward, and the spirit of the animal, which goes down to the earth?
So I perceived that nothing is*i better than that a man should rejoice in his own works, for that is*i his heritage. For who can bring him to see what will happen after him?
Ecclesiastes 4

Then*p I returned and considered all the oppression that is done under the sun: And*pn look! The tears of the oppressed, But*ld they have no comforter— On*ld the side of their oppressors there*i is*i power, But*ld they have no comforter.
Therefore*ld I praised the dead who were already dead, More*ld than the living who are still alive.
Yet,*ld better than both is*i he*i who has never existed, Who*ld has not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.
The Vanity of Selfish Toil
Again,*p I saw that for all toil and every skillful work a man is envied by his neighbor. This also is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
The*pn fool folds his hands And*ld consumes his own flesh.
Better*ld a handful with*i quietness Than*ld both hands full, together*i with*i toil and grasping for the wind.
Then*p I returned, and I saw vanity under the sun:

There*pn is one alone, without companion: He*ld has neither son nor brother. Yet*ld there*i is*i no end to all his labors, Nor*ld is his eye satisfied with riches. But*ild he never asks, “For*ld whom do I toil and deprive myself of good?” This*ld also is*i vanity and a grave misfortune.
The Value of a Friend
Two*pn are*i better than one, Because*ld they have a good reward for their labor.
For*ld if they fall, one will lift up his companion. But*ld woe to him who*i is*i alone when he falls, For*ld he*i has*i no one to help him up.
Again,*ld if two lie down together, they will keep warm; But*ld how can one be warm alone?*i
Though*ld one may be overpowered by another, two can withstand him. And*ld a threefold cord is not quickly broken.
Popularity Passes Away
Better*pn a poor and wise youth Than*ld an old and foolish king who will be admonished no more.
For*ld he comes out of prison to be king, Although*ld he was born poor in his kingdom.
I*ld saw all the living who walk under the sun; They*ld were with the second youth who stands in his place.
There*ild was*i no end of all the people over whom he was made king; Yet*ld those who come afterward will not rejoice in him. Surely*ld this also is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
Ecclesiastes 5
Fear God, Keep Your Vows
Walk*p prudently when you go to the house of God; and draw near to hear rather than to give the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they do evil.
Do*pn not be rash with your mouth, And*ld let not your heart utter anything hastily before God. For*ld God is*i in heaven, and you on earth; Therefore*ld let your words be few.
For*ld a dream comes through much activity, And*ld a fool’s voice is*i known*i by his*i many words.
When*ln you make a vow to God, do not delay to pay it; For*ld He*i has*i no pleasure in fools. Pay*ld what you have vowed—
Better*ld not to vow than to vow and not pay.
Do*p not let your mouth cause your flesh to sin, nor say before the messenger of*i God*i that it was*i an error. Why should God be angry at your excuse and destroy the work of your hands?
For in the multitude of dreams and many words there*i is*i also vanity. But fear God.
The Vanity of Gain and Honor

If*p you see the oppression of the poor, and the violent perversion of justice and righteousness in a province, do not marvel at the matter; for high official watches over high official, and higher officials are over them.
Moreover*p the profit of the land is for all; even*i the king is served from the field.
He*pn who loves silver will not be satisfied with silver; Nor*ld he who loves abundance, with increase. This*ld also is*i vanity.
When*ln goods increase, They*ld increase who eat them; So*ld what profit have the owners Except*ld to see them*i with their eyes?
The*ln sleep of a laboring man is*i sweet, Whether*ld he eats little or much; But*ld the abundance of the rich will not permit him to sleep.
There*ln is a severe evil which*i I have seen under the sun: Riches*ld kept for their owner to his hurt.
But*ld those riches perish through misfortune; When*ld he begets a son, there*i is*i nothing in his hand.
As*ld he came from his mother’s womb, naked shall he return, To*ld go as he came; And*ld he shall take nothing from his labor Which*ld he may carry away in his hand.
And*ln this also is*i a severe evil— Just*ld exactly as he came, so shall he go. And*ld what profit has he who has labored for the wind?
All*ld his days he also eats in darkness, And*ld he*i has*i much sorrow and sickness and anger.

Here*p is what I have seen: It*i is*i good and fitting for*i one*i to eat and drink, and to enjoy the good of all his labor in which he toils under the sun all the days of his life which God gives him; for it is*i his heritage.
As for every man to whom God has given riches and wealth, and given him power to eat of it, to receive his heritage and rejoice in his labor—this is*i the gift of God.
For he will not dwell unduly on the days of his life, because God keeps him*i busy with the joy of his heart.
Ecclesiastes 6
There*p is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it is*i common among men:

A man to whom God has given riches and wealth and honor, so that he lacks nothing for himself of all he desires; yet God does not give him power to eat of it, but a foreigner consumes it. This is*i vanity, and it is*i an evil affliction.

If*p a man begets a hundred children*i and lives many years, so that the days of his years are many, but his soul is not satisfied with goodness, or indeed he has no burial, I say that*i a stillborn child is*i better than he—
for it comes in vanity and departs in darkness, and its name is covered with darkness.
Though it has not seen the sun or known anything,*i this has more rest than that man,
even if he lives a thousand years twice—but has not seen goodness. Do not all go to one place?
All*pn the labor of man is*i for his mouth, And*ld yet the soul is not satisfied.
For*ld what more has the wise man*i than the fool? What*ld does the poor man have, Who*ld knows how*i to walk before the living?
Better*ld is*i the sight of the eyes than the wandering of desire. This*ld also is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
Whatever*ln one is, he has been named already, For*ld it is known that he is*i man; And*ld he cannot contend with Him who is mightier than he.
Since*ld there are many things that increase vanity, How*ld is*i man the better?
For*p who knows what is*i good for man in life, all the days of his vain life which he passes like a shadow? Who can tell a man what will happen after him under the sun?
Ecclesiastes 7
The Value of Practical Wisdom
A*p good name is*i better than precious ointment, And*pn the day of death than the day of one’s birth;
Better*ld to go to the house of mourning Than*ld to go to the house of feasting, For*ld that is*i the end of all men; And*ld the living will take it*i to heart.
Sorrow*ld is*i better than laughter, For*ld by a sad countenance the heart is made better.
The*ld heart of the wise is*i in the house of mourning, But*ld the heart of fools is*i in the house of mirth.
It*iln is*i better to hear the rebuke of the wise Than*ld for a man to hear the song of fools.
For*ld like the crackling of thorns under a pot, So*ld is*i the laughter of the fool. This*ld also is vanity.
Surely*ld oppression destroys a wise man’s*i reason, And*ld a bribe debases the heart.
The*ln end of a thing is*i better than its beginning; The*ld patient in spirit is*i better than the proud in spirit.
Do*ld not hasten in your spirit to be angry, For*ld anger rests in the bosom of fools.
Do*ld not say, “Why*ld were the former days better than these?” For*ld you do not inquire wisely concerning this.
Wisdom*ln is*i good with an inheritance, And*ld profitable to those who see the sun.
For*ld wisdom is*i a defense as*i money is*i a defense, But*ld the excellence of knowledge is*i that*i wisdom gives life to those who have it.
Consider*ln the work of God; For*ld who can make straight what He has made crooked?

In*ld the day of prosperity be joyful, But*ld in the day of adversity consider: Surely*ld God has appointed the one as well as the other, So*ld that man can find out nothing that*i will*i come*i after him.
I*p have seen everything in my days of vanity: There*pn is a just man*i who perishes in his righteousness, And*ld there is a wicked man*i who prolongs life*i in his wickedness.
Do*ld not be overly righteous, Nor*ld be overly wise: Why*ld should you destroy yourself?
Do*ld not be overly wicked, Nor*ld be foolish: Why*ld should you die before your time?
It*ild is*i good that you grasp this, And*ld also not remove your hand from the other; For*ld he who fears God will escape them all.
Wisdom*ln strengthens the wise More*ld than ten rulers of the city.
For*ln there*i is*i not a just man on earth who does good And*ld does not sin.
Also*ln do not take to heart everything people say, Lest*ld you hear your servant cursing you.
For*ld many times, also, your own heart has known That*ld even you have cursed others.
All*ln this I have proved by wisdom. I*ld said, “I will be wise”; But*ld it was*i far from me.
As*ld for that which is far off and exceedingly deep, Who*ld can find it out?
I*ld applied my heart to know, To*ld search and seek out wisdom and the reason of*i things,*i To*ld know the wickedness of folly, Even*ld of foolishness and*i madness.

And*ld I find more bitter than death The*ld woman whose heart is*i snares and nets, Whose*ld hands are*i fetters. He*ld who pleases God shall escape from her, But*ld the sinner shall be trapped by her.
Here*ln is what I have found,” says the Preacher, “Adding*ild one thing to the other to find out the reason,
Which*ld my soul still seeks but I cannot find: One*ld man among a thousand I have found, But*ld a woman among all these I have not found.
Truly,*ld this only I have found: That*ld God made man upright, But*ld they have sought out many schemes.”
Ecclesiastes 8
Who*pn is*i like a wise man?*i And*ld who knows the interpretation of a thing? A*ld man’s wisdom makes his face shine, And*ld the sternness of his face is changed.
Obey Authorities for God’s Sake
I*p say,*i “Keep the king’s commandment for the sake of your oath to God.
Do not be hasty to go from his presence. Do not take your stand for an evil thing, for he does whatever pleases him.”
Where*pn the word of a king is,*i there*i is*i power; And*ld who may say to him, “What are you doing?”
He*ld who keeps his command will experience nothing harmful; And*ld a wise man’s heart discerns both time and judgment,
Because*ld for every matter there is a time and judgment, Though*ld the misery of man increases greatly.
For*ld he does not know what will happen; So*ld who can tell him when it will occur?

No*ld one has power over the spirit to retain the spirit, And*ld no one has power in the day of death. There*ild is*i no release from that war, And*ld wickedness will not deliver those who are given to it.
All*p this I have seen, and applied my heart to every work that is done under the sun: There*i is*i a time in which one man rules over another to his own hurt.
Death Comes to All
Then*p I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the place of holiness, and they were forgotten in the city where they had so done. This also is*i vanity.
Because the sentence against an evil work is not executed speedily, therefore the heart of the sons of men is fully set in them to do evil.
Though a sinner does evil a hundred times,*i and his days*i are prolonged, yet I surely know that it will be well with those who fear God, who fear before Him.
But it will not be well with the wicked; nor will he prolong his*i days, which*i are*i as a shadow, because he does not fear before God.

There*p is a vanity which occurs on earth, that there are just men*i to whom it happens according to the work of the wicked; again, there are wicked men*i to whom it happens according to the work of the righteous. I said that this also is*i vanity.

So*p I commended enjoyment, because a man has nothing better under the sun than to eat, drink, and be merry; for this will remain with him in his labor all*i the days of his life which God gives him under the sun.
When*p I applied my heart to know wisdom and to see the business that is done on earth, even though one sees no sleep day or night,

then I saw all the work of God, that a man cannot find out the work that is done under the sun. For though a man labors to discover it,*i yet he will not find it;*i moreover, though a wise man*i attempts to know it,*i he will not be able to find it.*i
Ecclesiastes 9

For*p I considered all this in my heart, so that I could declare it all: that the righteous and the wise and their works are*i in the hand of God. People know neither love nor hatred by*i anything they*i see*i before them.

All things come*i alike to all: One*pn event happens*i to the righteous and the wicked; To*ld the good, the clean, and the unclean; To*ld him who sacrifices and him who does not sacrifice. As*ld is the good, so is*i the sinner; He*ld who takes an oath as he*i who fears an oath.

This*p is*i an evil in all that is done under the sun: that one thing happens*i to all. Truly the hearts of the sons of men are full of evil; madness is*i in their hearts while they live, and after that they*i go*i to the dead.
But for him who is joined to all the living there is hope, for a living dog is better than a dead lion.
For*pn the living know that they will die; But*ld the dead know nothing, And*ld they have no more reward, For*ld the memory of them is forgotten.
Also*ld their love, their hatred, and their envy have now perished; Nevermore*ld will they have a share In*ld anything done under the sun.
Go,*ln eat your bread with joy, And*ld drink your wine with a merry heart; For*ld God has already accepted your works.
Let*ld your garments always be white, And*ld let your head lack no oil.

Live*p joyfully with the wife whom you love all the days of your vain life which He has given you under the sun, all your days of vanity; for that is*i your portion in life, and in the labor which you perform under the sun.
Whatever*p your hand finds to do, do it*i with your might; for there*i is*i no work or device or knowledge or wisdom in the grave where you are going.

I*p returned and saw under the sun that— The*pn race is*i not to the swift, Nor*ld the battle to the strong, Nor*ld bread to the wise, Nor*ld riches to men of understanding, Nor*ld favor to men of skill; But*ld time and chance happen to them all.
For*ld man also does not know his time: Like*ld fish taken in a cruel net, Like*ld birds caught in a snare, So*ld the sons of men are*i snared in an evil time, When*ld it falls suddenly upon them.
Wisdom Superior to Folly
This*p wisdom I have also seen under the sun, and it seemed*i great to me:
There*i was*i a little city with few men in it; and a great king came against it, besieged it, and built great snares around it.
Now there was found in it a poor wise man, and he by his wisdom delivered the city. Yet no one remembered that same poor man.
Then*p I said: “Wisdom*pn is*i better than strength. Nevertheless*ld the poor man’s wisdom is*i despised, And*ld his words are not heard.
Words*ld of the wise, spoken*i quietly, should*i be*i heard Rather*ld than the shout of a ruler of fools.
Wisdom*ld is*i better than weapons of war; But*ld one sinner destroys much good.”
Ecclesiastes 10
Dead*pn flies putrefy the perfumer’s ointment, And*ld cause it to give off a foul odor; So*ild does*i a little folly to one respected for wisdom and*i honor.
A*ld wise man’s heart is*i at his right hand, But*ld a fool’s heart at his left.
Even*ld when a fool walks along the way, He*ld lacks wisdom, And*ld he shows everyone that*i he is*i a fool.
If*ld the spirit of the ruler rises against you, Do*ld not leave your post; For*ld conciliation pacifies great offenses.
There*ln is an evil I have seen under the sun, As*ld an error proceeding from the ruler:
Folly*ld is set in great dignity, While*ld the rich sit in a lowly place.
I*ld have seen servants on horses, While*ld princes walk on the ground like servants.
He*ln who digs a pit will fall into it, And*ld whoever breaks through a wall will be bitten by a serpent.
He*ld who quarries stones may be hurt by them, And*ild he who splits wood may be endangered by it.
If*ld the ax is dull, And*ld one does not sharpen the edge, Then*ld he must use more strength; But*ld wisdom brings success.
A*ln serpent may bite when it*i is*i not charmed; The*ld babbler is no different.
The*ld words of a wise man’s mouth are*i gracious, But*ld the lips of a fool shall swallow him up;
The*ld words of his mouth begin with foolishness, And*ld the end of his talk is*i raving madness.
A*ld fool also multiplies words. No*ld man knows what is to be; Who*ld can tell him what will be after him?
The*ld labor of fools wearies them, For*ld they do not even know how to go to the city!
Woe*ln to you, O land, when your king is*i a child, And*ld your princes feast in the morning!
Blessed*ld are*i you, O land, when your king is*i the son of nobles, And*ld your princes feast at the proper time— For*ld strength and not for drunkenness!
Because*ld of laziness the building decays, And*ld through idleness of hands the house leaks.
A*ld feast is made for laughter, And*ld wine makes merry; But*ld money answers everything.
Do*ln not curse the king, even in your thought; Do*ld not curse the rich, even in your bedroom; For*ld a bird of the air may carry your voice, And*ld a bird in flight may tell the matter.
Ecclesiastes 11
The Value of Diligence
Cast*pn your bread upon the waters, For*ld you will find it after many days.
Give*ld a serving to seven, and also to eight, For*ld you do not know what evil will be on the earth.
If*ln the clouds are full of rain, They*ld empty themselves*i upon the earth; And*ld if a tree falls to the south or the north, In*ld the place where the tree falls, there it shall lie.
He*ld who observes the wind will not sow, And*ld he who regards the clouds will not reap.
As*ln you do not know what is*i the way of the wind, Or*ild how the bones grow*i in the womb of her who is with child, So*ld you do not know the works of God who makes everything.
In*ld the morning sow your seed, And*ld in the evening do not withhold your hand; For*ld you do not know which will prosper, Either*ld this or that, Or*ld whether both alike will*i be*i good.
Truly*ln the light is sweet, And*ld it*i is*i pleasant for the eyes to behold the sun;
But*ld if a man lives many years And*ild rejoices in them all, Yet*ld let him remember the days of darkness, For*ld they will be many. All*ld that is coming is*i vanity.
Seek God in Early Life

Rejoice,*pn O young man, in your youth, And*ld let your heart cheer you in the days of your youth; Walk*ld in the ways of your heart, And*ld in the sight of your eyes; But*ld know that for all these God*ld will bring you into judgment.
Therefore*ld remove sorrow from your heart, And*ld put away evil from your flesh, For*ld childhood and youth are*i vanity.
Ecclesiastes 12
Remember*pn now your Creator in the days of your youth, Before*ld the difficult days come, And*ld the years draw near when you say, “I*ld have no pleasure in them”:
While*ld the sun and the light, The*ld moon and the stars, Are*ld not darkened, And*ld the clouds do not return after the rain;
In*ld the day when the keepers of the house tremble, And*ld the strong men bow down; When*ld the grinders cease because they are few, And*ld those that look through the windows grow dim;
When*ld the doors are shut in the streets, And*ld the sound of grinding is low; When*ld one rises up at the sound of a bird, And*ld all the daughters of music are brought low.

Also*ld they are afraid of height, And*ld of terrors in the way; When*ld the almond tree blossoms, The*ld grasshopper is a burden, And*ld desire fails. For*ld man goes to his eternal home, And*ld the mourners go about the streets.
Remember*iln your*i Creator*i before the silver cord is loosed, Or*ld the golden bowl is broken, Or*ld the pitcher shattered at the fountain, Or*ld the wheel broken at the well.

And*p moreover, because the Preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge; yes, he pondered and sought out and*i set in order many proverbs.
The Preacher sought to find acceptable words; and what*i was*i written was*i upright—words of truth.
